question: Does chronic aerobic exercise training enhance endothelium-dependent vasodilation via increased nitric oxide production compared with sedentary controls? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: CONCLUSIONS These results suggest that exercise training enhances bradykinin-induced vasodilation through increased endothelium-derived relaxing factor/nitric oxide production by the L-arginine/nitric oxide synthase pathway.
content.source_2: In sedentary animals, relaxation to the endothelium-dependent vasodilator bradykinin did not differ between collateral-dependent LCx and nonoccluded LAD arterioles (P>0.05), suggesting preserved endothelial NO-mediated responsiveness that is not further modified by chronic training.
content.source_3: After chronic coronary occlusion, treadmill exercise training reduced bradykinin-mediated relaxation in collateral-dependent LCx arterioles and was associated with lower ecNOS mRNA expression and decreased nitric oxide production.
